questions.text: A 2-year-old baby weighing 15 kg was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. He is afebrile, and there is no blood in his stools. The baby is lethargic. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retraction took more than two seconds. On offering water the child doesn't show eagerness to drink and responds poorly. Which of the following is correct with respect to the treatment of dehydration in this child?

choices.text: 600 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour
Zinc, antibiotics, and oral rehydration solution
450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour

questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has severe dehydration, as indicated by lethargy, sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (>2 seconds).

Severe dehydration requires treatment plan C. This involves using intravenous fluids (ringer lactate with 5% dextrose).

100ml/kg of fluid should be given over 3 hours in children of age more than 12 months. For those who are less than 12 months old, the fluid should be given over 6 hours.

Fluid requirement for severe dehydration is as follows:

Age 30 mL/kg 70 mL/kg
<12 months 1 hr 5 hr
>12 months 30 min 2.5 hr

 

Calculation of fluid required: The baby requires 30 mL/kg fluid and the weight of the baby is 15 kg. 

Therefore, the total fluid requirement is: 

15 kg x 30 mL/kg = 450 ml fluids in the first half-hour, and

15 kg x 70 mL/kg = 1050 ml over the next 2.5 hours.

questions.text: A 10-day-old female neonate with hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE) is hyper-alert with normal EEG. Examination shows hyperactive tendon reflexes, mydriatic pupil, and clonus.  What stage of HIE is she in?
questions.solution:
According to Sarnat staging of hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy (HIE), a hyperalert neonate with mydriatic pupil, hyperactive tendon reflex, clonus, and normal EEG belongs to stage 1. 

HIE is a brain injury that prevents adequate blood supply to the infant's brain. 

Sarnat staging of HIE:

Signs Stage 1 Stage 2  Stage 3
Level of consciousness Hyperalert Lethargic Stuporous, comatose
Muscle tone Normal Hypotonic Flaccid
Posture Normal Flexion Decerebrate
Tendon reflex/clonus Hyperactive Hyperactive Absent
Myoclonus Present Present Absent
Moro reflex Strong Weak Absent
Pupils Mydriasis Miosis Unequal, poor light reflex
Seizures None Common Decerebration
EEG findings Normal Low voltage changing to seizure activity

Burst suppression to isoelectric
Duration <24 hours if progress it; otherwise, can remain normal 24 hours to 14 days Days to weeks
Outcome Good Variable Death, severe deficits

Maternal causes for HIE are hypoventilation during anesthesia, cyanotic heart disease, respiratory failure, or carbon monoxide poisoning. Failure of oxygenation due to severe anemia, massive blood loss, and intracranial or adrenal hemorrhages are fetal causes of HIE. 

Hypoxia and ischemia cause anaerobic metabolism that generates a large amount of lactate and inorganic phosphates accumulation of toxic byproducts and overactivation of receptors. This leads to increased cellular permeability to sodium and calcium ions, resulting in cytotoxic edema and neuronal death. The most sensitive imaging modality for detecting hypoxic brain injury in neonates is an MRI.

Therapeutic hypothermia within the first 6 hours of life reduces mortality and major neurodevelopmental impairment. High-dose erythropoietin is used as an adjuvant to therapeutic hypothermia. Antiepileptic medications like phenobarbital and levetiracetam can be used to treat seizures. 

 Poor prognostic factors in HIE are:

  • Initial blood ph less than 6.7
  • Low (0-3) 10  in Apgar score
  • Delayed onset of spontaneous breathing
  • Seizure onset in less than 12 hours
  • Burst suppression pattern in EEG
  • Basal ganglia or thalamic lesion
  • Oliguria or anurias for more than 24 hours
  • Decerebrate posture

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. The minimum angle of resolution (MAR) in this patient is 2 minutes of arc. Which of the following correctly represents the visual acuity of this patient measured using Snellen's chart?
questions.solution:
The visual acuity in this patient according to Snellen's chart is 6/12.

The minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is a measure of visual acuity calculated by dividing the denominator of Snellen's fraction by the distance at which it was read- i.e, the Snellen's fraction is inverted and reduced. The formula is as follows:

MAR= 1/Visual acuity

Then Visual acuity = 1/MAR

Since in this patient, the MAR is given as 2 minutes of arc, visual acuity = 1/2. In order to represent the visual acuity with the numerator of 6, 1/2 can be written as 6/12.

Visual acuity is a measure of the spatial resolution of the eye or an estimation of its ability to discriminate between two points.

Snellen's chart consists of a series of letters arranged in lines, each diminishing in size such that at the nodal point of the eye at the given distance

  • The minimum angle of resolution is 1 minute of arc
  • Each whole letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes.

In the Snellen chart, the largest letter will subtend an angle of 5 minutes at the nodal point if it is 60 m from the eye. Those in the subsequent lines will subtend an angle of 5 minutes if they are 36, 24, 18, 12, 9, and 6 m from the eye.

Other options:

Option A: For acuity of 6/36, MAR = 36/6 = 6 minutes of arc

Option C: For acuity of 6/60, MAR = 60/6 = 10 minutes of arc

Option D: For acuity of 6/6, MAR = 6/6 = 1 minutes of arc

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. Which stage is it according to the FIGO staging of cervical cancer?

PET-CT - Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography
FIGO - International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging.

Cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer. The FIGO staging uses clinical, radiological, or pathological findings to stage cervical cancer from Stage I to IV.

Stage III cervical carcinoma involves the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, hydronephrosis, and lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

  • Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension
  • Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney
  • Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
    • Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only
    • Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Note: If the carcinoma had extended beyond the true pelvis, involving adjacent pelvic organs like the bladder or rectum, it would've been classified as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: A 51-year-old lady presents with complaints of a mass in the right breast. On examination, the mass was larger than 2cm and ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes were present. What is the staging, considering the mass is malignant?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a 51-year-old lady with a breast mass >2cm, lymph node involvement (N1), and the image showing an ulcerative mass near the nipple of the right breast (T4), is clinically suggestive of inflammatory breast carcinoma. Its likely staging is cT4N1M0

Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage T4) is an aggressive form of locally advanced breast cancer (LABC) and is associated with the worst prognosis among all subtypes of breast cancer. It accounts for <3% of breast cancers. It is characterized by skin changes of brawny induration, erythema, and edema (peau d’orange). The term peau d’orange describes the orange-peel appearance of the skin resulting from edema and dimpling at sites of hair follicles.

In order to determine the best course of treatment for a patient with IBC, it is important to stage cancer. Staging is the process of determining the extent to which cancer has spread within the breast and to other parts of the body. Some prefixes and suffixes are used with the cTNM (clinical) and pTNM (pathologic) staging systems to designate special cases. These do not affect the stage group but indicate that they must be analyzed separately. The “y” prefix, denotes patients who have received systemic therapy before surgery. In this patient, since the staging is being done clinically, "c" is added as a prefix. 

The diagnostic criteria for inflammatory breast cancer are - 

  • Rapid onset of breast erythema, edema and/or peau d’orange, and/or warm breast (with or without an underlying palpable mass)

  • Duration of history no more than six months

  • Erythema occupies at least one-third of the breast

  • Pathologic confirmation of invasive carcinoma

The pathologic hallmark is the presence of tumor cells within dermal lymphatics in skin biopsy specimens, but it is not a prerequisite for diagnosis.

Mammography may be normal or show skin thickening. A PET-CT scan should be considered at the time of diagnosis to rule out concurrent metastatic disease.

Axillary nodal metastases are common, and there is a significant risk for distant metastases.

Combined-modality treatment is used, which includes

  • Neoadjuvant chemo­therapy
  • Modified radical mastectomy
  • Radiation therapy
  • Hormonal therapy (for ER-positive tumors)
  • Trastuzumab (for HER-2-positive tumors)

 

Related Pearl: TNM Staging of carcinoma breast

Tumor (T) Description
Tis Ductal carcinoma in situ / Paget's disease
T1

≤2 cm in greatest dimension

1a >0.1 to 0.5 cm

1b >0.5 to 1 cm

1c >1 to 2 cm
T2 >2 but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension
T3 >5 cm in greatest dimension
T4

Tumor of any size and -

4a – chest wall involvement (except pectoralis major)# 

4b – skin involvement in the form of ulceration, peau d’orange, satellite nodules  

4c – 4a + 4b  

4d – inflammatory breast carcinoma(typical skin changes involving >1/3rd of breast)*
Nodes (N) Description
N1 mic Refers to micrometastasis to Lymph node
N1 Ipsilateral mobile axillary lymph nodes
N2A Ipsilateral fixed or matted axillary lymph nodes
N2B Ipsilateral internal mammary without axillary lymph node involvement
N3A Ipsilateral infraclavicular lymph nodes
N3B Ipsilateral internal mammary and axillary lymph nodes
N3C Ipsilateral supraclavicular lymph nodes
Distant metastasis (M) Description
Metastasis absent M0
Metastasis present M1

  

Stages       T , N  M
Stage 0 TisN0 M0
Stage IA T1N0 M0
Stage IB T0,1N1mic M0
Stage IIA T0,1N1 (or) T2N0 M0
Stage IIB T2N1 (or) T3N0 M0
Stage IIIA T0,1,2,3N2 (or) T3N1 M0
Stage IIIB T4 N0,1,2 M0
Stage IIIC

Any T, N3

Stage IV

Any T, Any N

#Chest wall includes Serratus anterior, Intercostal muscles, Ribs. Pectoralis muscle is not a part of chest wall.

*Inflammatory breast carcinoma (stage IIIB) is characterized by the skin changes of brawny induration, erythema with a raised edge, and edema (peaud’orange) involving >1/3rd of breast.

Note: LCIS (lobular carcinoma in situ) is considered as a benign condition and not included under Tis.

questions.text:
The serum electrolyte values of a patient weighing 60kg are given below. Calculate the sodium deficit in the patient. 
pH: 7.42, Na+: 120 mEq/L, serum K+: 4 mEq/L, serum Cl-: 90 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
The sodium deficit is calculated as (target sodium concentration-current sodium concentration) x 0.6 x Body weight (kg).

Substituting the values, sodium deficit = (140-120) x 0.6 x 60 = 720 mEq.

To calculate the sodium deficit in the patient, we first need to determine the target sodium concentration and compare it to the current sodium concentration.

The target sodium concentration can be calculated using the following formula:
Target Na concentration  = (Lower limit of serum sodium concentration + upper limit of serum sodium concentration) / 2

In this case, we assume the lower limit for the serum sodium concentration is 135 mEq/L, and the upper limit is 145 mEq/L.

Target Na concentration = (135 + 145) / 2= 140 mEq/L

Next, the current sodium deficit can be calculated using the following formula:
Sodium Deficit = (Target sodium concentration-current sodium concentration) x Total Body Water (TBW) 

Total Body Water (TBW) = Weight (in kg) × 0.6 (assuming 60% of body weight is water); TBW = 60 × 0.6= 36 liters

Sodium Deficit = (140 - 120) x 36 = 20 x 36 = 720 mEq

Therefore, the sodium deficit in the patient is 720 mEq.

Rapid sodium correction of 4–6 mEq/L should be achieved in the first 6 hours of therapy for patients with acute hyponatremia.

The rate of correction should be comparatively slow in chronic hyponatremia: <6-8 mEq/L in the first 24 h and <6 mEq/L each subsequent 24h, so as to avoid osmotic demyelination syndrome.

questions.text: You are examining an 18-year-old woman and it appears she has mature adult breasts. What is the Tanner stage of breast development in her?
questions.solution: The Tanner staging of the breast, in case of mature adult breast, is denoted as B5.

questions.text: While examining a pregnant woman, you measure her fundal height to be 32 cm and the station of the fetal head is at -2. What could be the probable weight of the fetus?
questions.solution:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.1Kg.

In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson's formula. Height of uterus is 32cm, the station is –2 implying the head is above the ischial spines. Therefore, it is calculated as follows: [32-12] x 155 = 3100 grams = 3.1Kg

Estimation of fetal weight:

  • Johnson’s formula: This is only applicable in vertex presentation.
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams
  • Sonography: Fetal weight has been estimated by combining a number of biometric data, e.g. biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL), using the following formulae:
    • Shepard’s formula
    • Hadlock’s formula.

questions.text: A researcher recently found out that the heart muscle has the highest arteriovenous oxygen difference of 120 ml/L. Considering that the lungs absorb 200 ml of O2 per minute from the atmosphere. What is the expected cardiac output?
questions.solution:
The expected cardiac output is 1.67 L/min.

Based on the Fick principle, cardiac output can be calculated by the following equation:

Cardiac output (L/min) = (O2 absorbed per minute by the lungs (mL/min)) / (Arterio-venous O2 difference (mL/L of blood)) 

In the given scenario:

  • The oxygen consumption of the heart muscle or the arteriovenous difference of the pulmonary artery and the pulmonary vein is 120 ml/L.
  • O2 absorbed by the lungs: 200ml/min

Hence cardiac output = 200 ml/min / 120 ml/L= 1.67 L/min 

Cardiac output is the amount of blood pumped by the heart into the aorta every minute. The average cardiac output is 5L/min and can be measured by various indirect methods.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with complaints of weight loss, hoarseness of voice, and difficulty in breathing. On direct laryngoscopy, a mass involving both the vocal cords with extension to the subglottis is seen. Cords are immobile and there is no lymph node involvement. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glottic carcinoma. What is the next step in the management of this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical picture of glottic carcinoma involving immobile vocal cords with extension to the subglottis suggests that the tumour belongs to the T3 stage. The treatment of choice is concurrent chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002)

Stage Description
T1 Tumour limited to vocal cord(s) with normal mobility
T1a Tumour limited to one vocal cord
T1b Tumour involves both vocal cords
T2a Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with normal vocal cord mobility
T2b Tumour extends to supraglottis and/or subglottis, with impaired vocal cord mobility
T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/or invades paraglottic space and/or  minor thyroid cartilage erosion
T4a Tumour invades thyroid cartilage and/or invades tissue beyond the larynx
T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal structures

Treatment of laryngeal cancers:

T stage Treatment
T1a TLM > RT
T1b (mid-cord lesion) RT/TLM > OPL
T2a RT/TLM > OPL
T2b RT ± CT > TLM
T3 CRT
T4a TL> CRT
T4b Palliative management

TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with an enlarged, hard, nodular prostate. Further investigations reveal a tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle. Other adjacent structures are not involved. What is the stage of his disease?
questions.solution:
The stage of the tumor that has extended through the prostatic capsule to the seminal vesicle and not to other adjacent structures is T3b.

Staging of prostate carcinoma:
Tx Primary tumor cannot be assessed
T0 No evidence of primary tumor
T1 Clinically inapparent tumor. Neither palpable nor visible on imaging
T1a Incidental histologic finding in 5% or less of tissue resected
T1b Incidental histologic findings in more than 5% of tissue resected
T1c Tumor identified by needle biopsy (for example, because of elevated PSA level)
T2

Tumor confined within the prostate
T2a

Tumor involves one-half of one lobe or less
T2b

Tumor involves more than one-half of one lobe but not both lobes
T2c

Tumor involves both lobes
T3

Tumors extend through the prostate capsule
T3a Extracapsular extension (unilateral or bilateral)
T3b

Tumor invades seminal vesicle(s)
T4 Tumor is fixed or invades adjacent structures other than seminal vesicles, such as external sphincter, rectum, bladder, levator muscles, and/or pelvic wall

questions.text: In a study, group A received a placebo while group B received a new drug. In group A,  36 deaths were reported out of a sample of 120. In group B, 26 deaths were reported out of a sample size of 130. Calculate the Absolute Risk Reduction (ARR) value.
questions.solution:
The value of Absolute Risk Reduction(ARR) in the given question is 10%.
 
The ARR(Absolute Risk Reduction) is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo group and the drug group. It is usually expressed in percentages.
Absolute Risk rate= No. of deaths/ sample population) x 100.
 
Calculation:
Step 1: Calculation of absolute risk rate
The absolute risk rate in group A (placebo)
= (36/120)x100
= 30%
The absolute risk rate in group B (new drug)
= (26/130)x100
= 20%
 
Step 2: Calculation of absolute risk reduction (ARR) = Absolute risk rate in group A - Absolute risk rate in group B
= 30 - 20
= 10%
Therefore the Absolute Risk Reduction in Group B as compared to the placebo group is 10%.
The Absolute Risk Reduction(ARR) signifies the proportion of people who benefitted from the new treatment/intervention over the existing treatment/placebo.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child weighing 40 Kg involved in a fire accident presented to the emergency room with 40% TBSA third-degree burns. What is the rate of initial fluid resuscitation required in this patient?

TBSA-Total body surface area

choices.text: 0.8 L over 8 hours, followed by 0.8 L over 16 hours
1.6 L over 8 hours, followed by 1.6 L over 16 hours
2.4 L over 8 hours, followed by 2.4 L over 16 hours
3.2 L over 8 hours, followed by 3.2 L over 16 hours

questions.solution:
The rate of initial fluid resuscitation required in this patient is 2.4 L over 8 hours, followed by 2.4 L over 16 hours.

As per the recent update in Advanced Trauma Life Support (ATLS) 10th edition (2018),  the fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years age is:

Percentage of burn x body weight (kg) x 3 = volume in ml

In this case, (percentage of burn) 40 x (body weight in kg) 40 x 3 = 4800ml

The volume in ml is 4800. Therefore volume in liters is 4.8 liters.

Half of the fluid is given in the first 8 hours of burns and the rest half in the next 16 hours.

Hence 2.4 litres has to be given in the first 8 hours, followed by 2.4 litres in the next 16 hours. 

#RecentUpdate: The initial fluid rate used for burns resuscitation has been updated by the American Burn Association to reflect concerns about over-resuscitation when using the traditional Parkland formula. According to the 10th Edition of ATLS (2018), fluid resuscitation in a pediatric patient < 14 years should begin at 3 ml of lactated Ringer’s x patient’s body weight in kg x % TBSA for second and third-degree burns. 

Note:

  • The superficial/1st-degree burns are not considered for the formula. Only the % TBSA of 2nd and 3rd-degree burns is calculated for the formula.
  • If the patient is < 1 year or < 30 kg body weight, then the fluid resuscitation will be 3 ml of lactated Ringer's lactate x patient's body weight in kg x % TBSA along with 5% dextrose at a maintenance rate.

questions.text: Which classification system is shown in the image below that is used to stage gastric cancer?
questions.solution:
The image shows Bormann classification used for advanced gastric cancer.

 Gastric carcinoma can be classified as early gastric cancer and advanced gastric cancer.

  • Early gastric cancer involves mucosa, submucosa with or without lymph node involvement. Early gastric cancer can be further classified using the Japanese classification.
  • Advanced gastric cancer involves the muscularis layer, with or without adjacent structures. Its macroscopic appearances have been classified using Bormann classification.

The given image shows the pathological types of early gastric cancer as per Japanese system.

Other options:

Option A: AJCC (American Joint Committee on Cancer) is for squamous cell carcinoma. It is classified based on the extent of differentiation. 

Option D: Hinchey classification is used for diverticulitis.

Related Pearl: Borrmann’s classification of stomach cancer

questions.text:
Calculate the anion gap from the following values:
Na+ = 137 mmol/L
K+ = 4 mmol/L
Cl- = 100 mmol/L
HCO3- = 15 mmol/L
questions.solution:
The anion gap is the difference between measured cations and measured anions and is estimated as:

Anion gap = [Na+] – ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])

Substituting the given values, AG is 22 mmol/L. Normal AG is 6 to 12 mmol/L with an average of 10 mmol/L.

The concentrations of anions and cations in plasma must be equal to maintain electrical neutrality. Therefore, there is no real “anion gap” in the plasma.

However, only certain cations and anions are routinely measured in the clinical laboratory. The cation normally measured is Na+, and the anions are usually Cl− and HCO3−. The value of plasma potassium is omitted from the calculation of the anion gap.

Usually, the unmeasured anions exceed the unmeasured cations.

The anion gap will increase if unmeasured anions rise or if unmeasured cations fall.

The unmeasured anions include albumin, phosphate, sulfate, and other organic anions. The unmeasured cations include calcium, magnesium, and potassium.

questions.text: A patient underwent laparoscopic cholecystectomy for cholelithiasis. Specimen revealed that she had gall bladder carcinoma infiltrating the muscularis layer. What is the management?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, gallbladder carcinoma with T1b lesions is detected incidentally after cholecystectomy. Treatment guidelines for the same are as follows:

  • Up to stage Ia and stage Ib with negative margins, a standard cholecystectomy would suffice.
  • Stage Ib with perineural, lymphovascular invasion, positive cystic duct margins, or poor differentiation, and stage II, extended cholecystectomy should be performed. Extended cholecystectomy involves the removal of the gall bladder, segments IVB and V of the liver, and lymph nodes along the hepatoduodenal ligament, with or without removal of the common bile duct (CBD).

However, the likelihood of nodal disease increases significantly with T1b lesions and perineural, lymphatic, or vascular invasion, therefore, extended cholecystectomy is generally recommended for all patients who are medically fit with T1b or greater level of invasion.

If the initial procedure was performed laparoscopically, the surgeon should examine the laparoscopic port sites. The finding of disease at the port sites is a sign of generalized peritoneal disease and carries a very poor prognosis. However, resection of port sites is no longer recommended.

Chemotherapy is not required in early gallbladder cancer. Radiation has no role.

Treatment of gallbladder carcinoma:

TNM staging Treatment
T1a Simple cholecystectomy
T1b, T2, T3 Radical cholecystectomy
T4 Unresectable, chemotherapy and palliative nonsurgical therapy are provided
N1 Regional lymphadenectomy
N2 Radical cholecystectomy plus hepatopancreatic duodenectomy

questions.text: According to the TNM staging, a lung cancer of 2.5 cm is staged as:
questions.solution:
T1c is the T stage of lung carcinoma of size 2.5cm not involving the main bronchus according to TNM staging.

Minimally invasive adenocarcinoma

Tumour 1 cm in greatest dimension

T1b

Tumor>1 cm but ≤2 cm in greatest dimension

T1c

Tumor>2 cm but ≤3 cm in greatest dimension

T2

Tumor>3 cm but ≤5 cm or tumor with any of the following features:c
– involves the main bronchus regardless of distance from the carina but without the involvement of the carina
– invades visceral pleura
– associated with atelectasis or obstructive pneumonitis that extends to the hilar region, involving part or all of the lung

T2a

Tumor>3 cm but ≤4 cm in greatest dimension

T2b

Tumor>4 cm but ≤5 cm in greatest dimension

T3

Tumor>5 cm but ≤7 cm in greatest dimension or associated with separate tumor nodule(s) in the same lobe as the primary tumor or directly invades any of the following structures: chest wall (including the parietal pleura and superior sulcus tumors), phrenic nerve, the parietal pericardium

T4

Tumor>7 cm in greatest dimension or associated with separate tumor nodule(s) in a different ipsilateral lobe than that of the primary tumor or invades any of the following structures: diaphragm, mediastinum, heart, great vessels, trachea, recurrent laryngeal nerve, esophagus, vertebral body, and carina

N: Regional lymph nodes involvement

 

Nx

Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0

No regional lymph node metastasis

N1

Metastasis in ipsilateral peribronchial and/or ipsilateral hilar lymph nodes and intrapulmonary nodes, including involvement by direct extension

N2

Metastasis in ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s)

N3

Metastasis in contralateral mediastinal, contralateral hilar, ipsilateral or contralateral scalene, or supraclavicular lymph node(s)

M: Distant metastasis

 

M0

No distant metastasis

M1

Distant metastasis present

M1a

Separate tumor nodule(s) in a contralateral lobe; tumor with pleural or pericardial nodule(s) or malignant pleural or pericardial effusion

M1b

Single extrathoracic metastasize

M1c

Multiple extrathoracic metastases in one or more organs

questions.text: The clearance of a drug which follows first-order kinetics (in one compartment model) is 0.2 L/min and volume of distribution is 40 L. What is the t1/2 of that drug?
questions.solution:
The t1/2 of the drug would be 140 minutes.

t1/2 is the time required for the plasma concentration or the amount of a drug in the body to be reduced by 50%. It depends on its clearance and volume of distribution. 

t1/2 = 0.693 x Vd/Cl

where Vd is the volume of distribution and Cl is clearance.

We can take 0.693 approximately as 0.7.

Vd = 40 L

CL= 0.2 L/min

Substituting,

t1/2 = 0.7 x 40 /0.2

t1/2 = 0.7 x 200

t1/2 = 140 minutes

Clinical implications: Half-life determines the length of the drug effect. It also indicates whether the accumulation of the drug will occur under a multiple dosage regimen and it is essential to decide on the appropriate dosing interval.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
questions.solution:
Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis.

It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. 

Diagnosis:

  • In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm.
  • In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm.

The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment:

  • Grade 1: <50% stenosis
  • Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis
  • Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis
  • Grade 4: No lumen detected

Other options

Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma.

Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system.

Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway
